newsitem.title: USA: Clinton issues guidelines on religious freedom.
newsitem.headline: Clinton issues guidelines on religious freedom.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton issued executive guidelines on Thursday ordering federal agencies to give government employees as much freedom as possible to engage in religious worship in the workplace.
"Religious freedom is at the heart of what it means to be an American," Clinton said at a ceremony announcing the new guidelines.
Clinton said the new rules clarify:
- that federal employees may engage in personal religious expression to the greatest extent possible;
- that employers may not discriminate in employment on the basis of religion;
- and that employers must reasonably accommodate employees' religious practices.

"These guidelines will ensure that federal employees and employers will respect the rights of those who engage in religious speech as well as those who do not," said Clinton, a Southern Baptist and regular churchgoer.

A copy of the guidelines released by the White House said federal employers must accommodate an employee "when work schedules interfere with Sabbath or other religious holiday observances or when work rules prevent an employee from wearing religiously compelled dress."

In addition, an agency must prevent any supervisor or any employee from engaging in religious harassment or creating "a religiously hostile environment" through the use of intimidation, ridicule or insult.
